p: Despite the availability of potent antivirals and vaccination against the hepatitis B virus (HBV), chronic HBV infection remains a significant socioeconomic burden. The global prevalence of chronic HBV in 2016 was close to 3.9%, which equates to approximately 292 million HBsAg-positive individuals, making it one of the most common human pathogens, and there is large regional variation[ 1]. In addition to its effects on the liver, patients with HBV have extrahepatic manifestations of renal disease. In a single-center retrospective trial, Zhang et al[ 2] reported that 3% (n = 352) of a total of 11,618 kidney biopsies performed from 1987 to 2012 in Beijing, China, were HBV-GN positive.
